task.summary: Default task
Brought the network creating functions within the evolvednetwork class - if we make network types instances of the class then we don't really need a separate class for creating networks anyway.
Added a negative control random matrix for testing too.
Changed the number of network files (want a minimal number of networks if I'm uploading to Anne's machine)

Created a bounding function to bound the calculations by, as many population nodes were of the order 10^35 previous after 4000 steps
Also changed destination of output files for the vas1 machine - hopefully will tidy things up a bit
Changed the bound from int to float to accommodate rd.uniform
Re-named bound to pos_real_bound as rd.uniform appeared to be interpreting the argument bound as the function
Re-named bound to pos_real_bound as rd.uniform appeared to be interpreting the argument bound as the function
Changed the output data types to integers to accommodate banjo (wouldn't recognise the floats)
Removed the troubleshooting message
Re-shuffled where I'm making the term an integer, as vas1 machine threw an error
Got rid of \ in file names as was preventing banjo from reading it. Also removed int on the variables as want to test if banjo can handle floats
Got rid of \ in file names as was preventing banjo from reading it. Also removed int on the variables as want to test if banjo can handle floats
Nothing, just re-saving to see if the vas1 file is incorrect
Transposed the output matrices to conform to banjo
Transposed the output matrices to conform to banjo
Changed output data to int to see if floats are preventing banjo from functioning
Changed output data to int to see if floats are preventing banjo from functioning
round() rather than int() as int() failing

Removed decimal module, unnecessary. Can alter the format which the numpy arrays are written to .x.t files with using fmt = ''. Specified 6 decimal places for the time being, may increase this in future.
Added a function for writing arrays to files that condenses the code, called save_txt(). Also specified tab delimiters for the data outputs, as required by Banjo.

Adding in code which generates individual datasets for each given network - set default to 10.
Decided that the easiest thing to do is to have extinction networks as an independent class from gene regulatory networks
Forgot to add in replicate number on the file output names in the last commit
Generated a file that recursively generates Banjo settings files within its directory. No file history as worked in a test directory to develop it.
Added a template variable which stores the location of the banjo settings file template
Network_evaluator is a housekeeping/data collecting file that scores how well the solved network recovers the true network, and draws output networks

Re-named network generator.py to allow easier working from command line
Struggling currently to keep species extinct, using round(x, 6) to round to 6 decimal places as would be displayed in output file, however still getting extinction

Created milns_discretiser.py, file which converts data.txt files into discretised form for Banjo analysis, following the method in Milns et al, 2010.
Added dynamic option for extinction networks, where iterations are taken to be time points, and the time increases down the file.
Created get_surface.py, which examines the behaviour of the search by plotting the network score vs best network number
Created data_processor.py, which reads moth data for Banjo analysis

MESSAGE.value: Brought the network creating functions within the evolvednetwork class - if we make network types instances of the class then we don't really need a separate class for creating networks anyway.
Added a negative control random matrix for testing too.
Changed the number of network files (want a minimal number of networks if I'm uploading to Anne's machine)

Created a bounding function to bound the calculations by, as many population nodes were of the order 10^35 previous after 4000 steps
Also changed destination of output files for the vas1 machine - hopefully will tidy things up a bit
Changed the bound from int to float to accommodate rd.uniform
Re-named bound to pos_real_bound as rd.uniform appeared to be interpreting the argument bound as the function
Changed the output data types to integers to accommodate banjo (wouldn't recognise the floats)
Removed the troubleshooting message
Re-shuffled where I'm making the term an integer, as vas1 machine threw an error
Got rid of \ in file names as was preventing banjo from reading it. Also removed int on the variables as want to test if banjo can handle floats
Nothing, just re-saving to see if the vas1 file is incorrect
Transposed the output matrices to conform to banjo
Changed output data to int to see if floats are preventing banjo from functioning
round() rather than int() as int() failing

Removed decimal module, unnecessary. Can alter the format which the numpy arrays are written to .x.t files with using fmt = ''. Specified 6 decimal places for the time being, may increase this in future.
Added a function for writing arrays to files that condenses the code, called save_txt(). Also specified tab delimiters for the data outputs, as required by Banjo.

Adding in code which generates individual datasets for each given network - set default to 10.
Decided that the easiest thing to do is to have extinction networks as an independent class from gene regulatory networks
Forgot to add in replicate number on the file output names in the last commit
Generated a file that recursively generates Banjo settings files within its directory. No file history as worked in a test directory to develop it.
Added a template variable which stores the location of the banjo settings file template
Network_evaluator is a housekeeping/data collecting file that scores how well the solved network recovers the true network, and draws output networks

Re-named network generator.py to allow easier working from command line
Struggling currently to keep species extinct, using round(x, 6) to round to 6 decimal places as would be displayed in output file, however still getting extinction

Created milns_discretiser.py, file which converts data.txt files into discretised form for Banjo analysis, following the method in Milns et al, 2010.
Added dynamic option for extinction networks, where iterations are taken to be time points, and the time increases down the file.
Created get_surface.py, which examines the behaviour of the search by plotting the network score vs best network number
Created data_processor.py, which reads moth data for Banjo analysis
